noun.description: An object that one need not, cannot, or does not wish to give a specific name to.
examples: look at that metal rail thing over there
there are lots of things I'd like to buy
she was wearing this pink thing

noun.description: An inanimate material object as distinct from a living sentient being.
examples: I'm not a thing, not a work of art to be cherished

noun.description: An action, activity, event, thought, or utterance.
examples: she said the first thing that came into her head
the only thing I could do well was cook
you need a tonic—and here's just the thing

noun.description: Used to introduce or emphasize an important point.
examples: the thing is, I am going to sell this house
here's the thing: this is a story, not a piece of hard news
that's the thing about style—no two people are completely alike

phrases: Of course, just as SAC cannot be all things to all people, the cultural strategy will not please everyone or meet all needs.
The government can't be all things to all people.
The Liberals want to be all things to all people.
Simply put, like the Toronto event, it is expected to be all things to all people.
And it may require the reallocation of some of our resources, and we're going to have to understand that we can't be all things to all people.
origin: Old English, of Germanic origin; related to German Ding. Early senses included meeting and matter, concern as well as inanimate object.
